Dr. ___  
Cardiology Department  
___ Hospital  

Dear ___,

I am providing a summary of your recent hospital stay from March 10 to March 12, 2024, following your presentation to our facility with chest pain and shortness of breath.

Upon admission on March 10, an electrocardiogram (ECG) indicated significant ST elevation in leads V5-V6, suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction. A diagnosis of ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left main coronary artery was subsequently confirmed on March 11. Initial management followed the MONAC protocol and included administration of morphine, oxygen, aspirin, and nitroglycerin to alleviate pain and support myocardial perfusion.

We faced challenges initiating percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) due to unavailability at the cath lab as well as communication delays. Despite these hurdles, our efforts focused on stabilizing your condition, monitoring serial Troponin T levels, which were markedly elevated at 30 and then 29, indicative of myocardial injury.

Throughout your stay, you received necessary medications: morphine for pain as needed, oxygen to maintain saturation levels above 90%, nitroglycerin for ongoing pain, and a single dose of aspirin. Fortunately, your chest pain resolved, prompting your request for discharge after monitoring through the night of March 12.

As you prepare to return home, it is essential to continue follow-up care with your primary cardiologist to discuss further management, potential lifestyle modifications, and any necessary additional interventions. Please ensure to have rest and avoid strenuous activities until you have clearance from your healthcare provider.

Should you experience any recurrence of chest pain, difficulty breathing, or other concerning symptoms, do not hesitate to seek medical attention immediately.

Thank you for entrusting us with your care. We wish you a swift recovery and are available should you have any further questions or need assistance.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___  
Cardiology Staff
